pull.title: test: allow all functional tests to be run or skipped with --usecli
pull.body:
Fixes #32264

I looked into all current failures listed in the issue, as well all tests that are already disabled for the cli with `self.supports_cli = False`. There are several reasons why existing tests fail  with `--usecli` on many systems, the most important ones are:

- Most common reason is that the test executes a RPC call with a large arg that `execve` doesn't support (the limit is 128kb on my ubuntu system): Disabled these tests for now for the cli via `self.supports_cli = False`. 
 One idea for a fix would be to add an option `-rpcfromfile` to `bitcoin-cli` that would allow us to read the full command from a (possibly temporary) file instead of passing it directly - this could be used by the functional test framework, but might be useful in general for people who want to use the cli instead of the rpc interface. Any opinions on this?
- Some functional test submit wrong types to params on purpose to test the error message (which is different when using the cli) - deactivated these specific subtests locally for the cli when there is just one or two of them, since this is usually just a small independent part of the test.
Fixed some tests directly:
- When python sets `None` for an arg, the cli converts this to 'null' in `arg_to_cli`. This is fine e.g. for boolean args, but doesn't work for strings where it's interpreted as the string 'null'. Bypass this for named args by not including args in case the value is `None` for the cli is used (it's effectively the same as leaving the optional arg out).
-  the `height_or_hash` param used in some RPC needs to be converted to a JSON (effectively adding full quotes).

events.message: test: fix rpc_deprecated.py to be usable with --usecli

test: make rpc_psbt.py usable with --usecli

The psbt string would include a "=" sign, which would
make the cli interpret this as a named argument.
Fix this by making it an actual named arg with the
correct name.

test: convert tuple to json for cli

This makes it possible to run rpc_createmultisig.py with --usecli.

test: Don't send empty named args with cli

If python passed None for an optional (i.e. 'null' is
sent), this will lead to the arg being interpreted as not
provided by bitcoind - except for string args, for which the arg is
interpreted as as 'null' string. Bypass this by not sending
named args to bitcoin-cli - so that the default value will
actually be used. The issue still persists for positional args,
but the existing test "wallet_labels.py" affected by this can
be changed to use named args instead.

This also makes wallet_labels.py --usecli no longer fail.

test: add function to convert to json for height_or_hash params

This is necessary for bitcoin-cli because a string without quotes
is not a valid json.

test: skip subtests that check for wrong types with cli

The error messages returned for wrong type differ betwen
using rpc or cli - skip these subtests where they happen.

test: Disable several (sub)tests with cli

Reason for each test:
wallet_labels.py: uses createmultiwallet, which is currently not
compatible with cli
rpc_whitelist.py: Relies on direct RPC calls
wallet_encryption.py: Null characters cannot be passed to
suprocess.Popen, which is used to send the commands to
bitcoin-cli.

test: Disable tests for cli that make large RPC calls

These tests send off large rpc calls (e.g.by submitting large txns or blocks)
that exceed the limit of execve (128kb on many systems) when using cli.

comments.body: Hmm, this is only an issue because  `hash_or_height` expects a JSON object, not a string (and a text without quotes is no valid JSON object), so regular string args don't need this. I think the current naming is confusing, maybe renaming the function "`convert_to_json_for_cli`" and calling `json.dumps(text)` inside instead of adding quotes (in case the cli is used) would be better to convey why this is done? Or is there a better solution?
